Authentic Spanish tapas, made with love! When my husband and I first found this place on our Honeymoon in 2010, I didn't know what to expect. Having only tried paella once or twice previously, my knowledge of Spanish food was limited (to say the least). My husband, however, lived in Spain for several years as a child. But he was worried that he wouldn't remember the names of the dishes he had loved decades before. We opened the menus and my husband's face lit up with excitement. There were pictures next to each dish! He quickly pointed out three tapas we had to try. I found two more that sounded good. (If you're following along at home, that's FIVE tapas for two people. God help us.) We proceeded to eat for the next two hours. We ate until it hurt. Every dish was delicious and authentic.  We've returned many times over the years, introducing many of our friends to this gem of a restaurant. It's great for a party of two or ten. So...what are you doing still reading? Go eat already!

Best restaurant for the value, flavor, and convenience. I made reservations here for a party of 6 on a Thursday evening and they were incredibly accommodating with pushing back the time and later calling to say we were running later. The place is pretty large so you shouldn't have an issue with reservations. If I lived in Chicago, I would totally love to have my birthday dinner here! Onto the food: Salpicon De Mariscos mixed seafood salad with shrimp, octopus and squid: all of the seafood was so nicely seasoned and tender, pretty impressed  Patatas Ali-Oli Red potatoes with garlic mayonnaise sauce: Omg heart attack of mayo overload but I LUV mayo and the combo with garlic so nicely slathered I woulda never thought to mix on my own, loved it! Patatas Bravas Spicy potatoes with special tomato sauce-not really spicy but didn't want it to be; it was alright, we had too many potatoes. Pincho de Pollo Chicken brochette with caramelized onions and rice-yum yum yum, nicely cooked and I gobbled up those onions Pincho de Solomillo Skewered beef tenderloin with fries and caramelized onions-didn't really care for the beef which tasted more like sausages and I was expecting more steak Datiles con Jamon Dates stuffed with goat cheese and wrapped in Spanish ham; served with rice and raisins-too much date or sweet taste and not enough ham for the savory part Raxo Adobado Marinated pork loin served with home made fries-I liked dipping the French fries from this dish into all the other sauces from other dishes Mejillones a la Marinera Steamed mussels with marinara sauce-would order again! Paella Iberica A Cafe Iberico original, served with seafood, chicken and pork-not the best paella in the entire world since it could use a lil more marination of seafood flavor the rice but it satisfies my paella craving, price is unbeatable and so is portion size (fed 6!)--it's pretty good! Sangria $17.95 for a pitcher to fill 6-large water drinking glasses, not just tiny lil wine glasses. I want to go back already!!

At first glance this place is nothing noteworthy. The inside is questionable in terms of cleanliness and the menu options are pretty basic. One thing that did wow me was their margarita! It was delicious. I was a tad shocked to discover it cost a ridiculous $12 but it was worth it! Unfortunately, that is not something I can say for the rest of the meal. We had the goat cheese with tomato, the chorizo plate, the croquetas and the palleta iberico. All of these were just average, but the chorizo plate was straight up kinda gross. Some of the sausages tasted burnt and others were weirdly chewy. I do not recommend this place for a date or anything special, but if you're looking for basic tapas, it's fine.
Sadly we were told this was a must when we visited Chi town ! We have had an amazing experience with food thus far but it was a major let down.

Cafe Iberico is a Spanish Tapas style restaurant located in River North/ Streeterville, Chicago. It is a Chicago staple and I've been a few times now. My latest visit was pretty mediocre unfortunately. It wasn't too crowded, and I came in with a small group of girls for dinner, we were seated immediately and our server was very attentive, like never left the table attentive. We ordered a few appetizers to start, we as a group really like to chat, catch up, enjoy our food and our drinks, but we felt SO RUSHED. Our server and the other bus boys would not stop coming over to our table to ask if we were finished, and clearing plates that we were not finished with yet. It was so awkward.  We ordered a few more plates to share, but when the server a bus boys started stand AROUND our table and clearing plates, using the crummer, and refilling, already full waters, we were over it. we got the check and left for the next place.  They were not crowded at all and we asked if they needed our table, but they said no, It was so uncomfortable that we had to leave. We would have stayed for much longer and ordered a lot more food and drinks if we would have felt a bit more relaxed.  I will not be returning.

Our table of 4 was so disappointed. While waiting for our dinner table, we ordered drinks at the bar and before we could cash out the seater was clearly irritated to wait for us to do so. She ran waaaay ahead of us all and we could barely find her. The place was so loud we couldn't do anything but read lips at the table. Blaring music. If the food was better we might have been ok with the noise but nope. Gazpacho was equal to cold Campbell's. None of us liked our food. They served it to us willy-nilly - one person had 3 items while others had zero. It took forever to get drinks from the waiter. We went out the next night together and the entire topic of conversation was how bad Cafe Imberico was. I gave 2 stars based on our waiter was nice although not very attentive. All around a bad experience.
Pulpo a la plancha is outstanding!!! Want More! Sangria is great too and a price is more than affordable!  The place is noisy I have to admit, but it was Sunday!  Thanks for a great evening!
Unique Interior design that is fun and captivating. The food is amazing!  First Timers: - Order: Cazuela de Carne Asada

Good tapas but HORRIBLE service and environment. I have been coming here for many years, brought many friends, coordinated work dinners and recommended this place. But over the years the wervice and quality has gotten worse. I was there this wek with a friend and we had the most disappointing experience.  We walked in as the valet attendant was walking out and rather than holding the door for us to catch, he closed it. Once we reached the hostess's desk she was busy talking to the staff and didn't see us until she was done. As soon as we were seated the server arrived, handed the menus and asked if we were ready to order. No time to sit, open the menu and look. We had to ask him to come back. The bus boy arrived in seconds with water and bread which he placed on top of the menus and walked away. Both very unfriendly, not a hello or names were provided.  We ordered quickly, the food came out and the place was so cold the food was cold within minutes. The tapas used to be great, now they are good and nothing out of this world. My recommendation would be to NOT go!

big place.....noisy.....good service...great food.  the steak skewers, grilled octopus, baked goat cheese, croquettes and potato salad are a must.  i have taken large parties here several times and it never disappoints.

I love that they serve by portions here, so you can get multiple items and share with whoever you come with. I settled on shrimp, rice and a few different types of potatoes (hot and cold). The dishes were very good. I wanted a frozen margarita, which they don't normally serve but they made an exception for me. I enjoyed it! My friend had the sangria and said it was delicious. I recommend stopping by and I will be back!

I've actually been to this place a million times over ten years I've been eating here, and let me tell you I've never been disappointed tons of different little dishes to choose from ( Tapas ) calamari, potatoes cold or hot, the ones simmered in tomato sauce are my favorite nice little spice to them delicious, one of my personal favorites there is the octopus with fries bomb! Can't stop eating it octopus is nice and tender that's no easy feat, had the seafood salad for the first time last night that was really good and of course I had to order the goat cheese in tomato sauce served nice and hot awesome, I could go on and on about the dishes because I've had soooo many over the years, if this is your first time here the tapas are small so order a bunch of little dishes and share that's what I always do it works great, big crowds at night do expect a little wait it's chaotic but they manage they get people in and out quick, service is good even tho it's really loud at night music people talking etc.... Food comes pretty quick full bar I love the sangria very refreshing, no reservations here either lunch time is not as hectic at all, prices are good too not expensive, only complaint I've ever had here is sometimes depending on the hostess they could be a bit rude and stuck up, but other than that I've tried other Spanish restaurants and this is simply the best to me, rude hostesses don't ruin the experience so don't worry just a little aggravating but great restaurant.
Tapas are so so. Paella though was not bad for the price. Restaurant could improve on service and the background music was quite too loud.

Sangria drink is perfect! Sweet and refreshing.  I shared a vegetarian paella with my husband but, it is huge so you can definitely share it with 4 people. We ended up nothing eating it at all just because we were already filled up. You gotta be hungry to start off. Anyway, this is a nice place for family and friends gathering.

Long-time customer lost.  I've been a guest at Cafe Iberico for over 5 years now. I was introduced to it by friends, and made several introductions myself. It is was definitely our go-to spot for any special occasion: birthday celebrations, graduations, anniversaries, bringing out-of-towners for dinner, etc. However, after a bad experience and learning of other options in the area, I decided to check out those other restaurants. Did not look back. However, last night, our group of friends decided to stop by for dinner and drinks. Worst. Choice. Ever. Food was just eh. Not terrible, but nothing to enjoy either. Service was horrible, and it extended beyond the server. And do not think of ever reaching a manager there. I've left several messages in the past, and never received any type of response. Will not return.
I had my birthday today there. It's perfect. The food was great, staffs were nice even though I dropped a plate. Absolutely back there
Great service,consistently delicious Spanish food , great atmosphere inside, diverse crowds and price wise ! affordable if we compare it to downtown restaurants prices.

Meh, I was underwhelmed by Cafe Iberico.  The service was decent; our server was attentive and we didn't wait long for anything. But the food wasn't impressive. It wasn't bad...it was just ok. The prices weren't justifiable. I had just one slice of "free" table bread - it was flavorless. The rest of the dishes were forgettable. The interior was ok. Not the most comfortable or appealing. The atmosphere was off. It felt like a clubby River North bar instead of a restaurant. My group was seated downstairs near a few other tables of large parties. There was a lot of loud chanting and yelling. It was weird. On principle, I never recommend a competitor in my reviews, but I'm gonna brake my own rule and suggest dining at Cafe Baba Reba, in Lincoln Park, if you want delicious Spanish tapas in a classy atmosphere.

I have been to this place a couple of time and It never deceives. The Food is sooooo goood! The service can be slow sometimes as they get really packed and busy. But it is still one of my favorite restaurant in Chicago. The grilled Octopus is very popular and it is the BEST octopus I ever had. My other favorite is the Jarrete de Cordero (Slow roasted lamb shank simmered with red wine).

If you want tapas, go elsewhere. We came to Chicago from Philly for an extended weekend.  Cafe Iberico looked like a great spot with so many good reviews and its close proximity to our hotel on the Magnificent Mile. We already wanted to leave after we were seated.  We were provided with laminated menus with pictures of each dish - this was a warning sign to us that we should have left.  However, we had a flight to catch with no other dining options nearby. We ordered the dates, mushrooms, patatas bravas, and beef skewers.  Somehow, everything came out of the kitchen within 10 minutes.  I wouldn't be surprised if they had just microwaved our food - it certainly tasted that way.  The potatoes were mushy and did not seem authentic, compared to our Spanish tapas experiences in Philadelphia.  The dates were very small and the ham was dry and shriveled up.  I wish we had gone elsewhere - it was a waste of a potentially good culinary experience in Chicago.

Fantastic. Can't say enough how much I enjoyed this place. Authentic Spanish tapas, blaring Latin music vids on the numerous tvs decorating the joint. The dishes we ordered were all delicious and cheap, servers were friendly and a great Friday night ambiance. Really enjoyed date night here. A must go.

Was hoping for more. I think there are just so many better options around, and it felt really overpriced for what I was getting. Tapas were $10-15, which takes the fun out of getting a few tapas as an entree. At that point, I can just get a large entree elsewhere.  I wouldn't necessarily discourage someone from going here, but I probably won't be back.

I remember when this place was all the hype. Still not bad- plenty of choices in parking, nice area on Lasalle. Nice rustic dining room. Food was pretty good we had the cheese and meat platter, scallops, shrimp, and finally the paella. The shrimp and scallops were good..nothing mind blowing. The meats were plenty but only 2 paper thin slices of cheese. Bread was good. Paella was good- lots of ham, chicken and seafood in it. Rice was nice and fluffy- fresh peas. For dessert we ordered the crepe which left much to be desired. Not much flavor just a thin crepe with ice cream and strawberry sauce. Mocha was warm till I had it replaced with a hot one. Not a terrible experience--just nice tapas in the city. A-OK.
The paella was delicious!!!!! We went on a Saturday night and it was super duper packed!! Sangria was tasty!

The pulpo a la plancha and the mussels "a la marinera" are my favorite. The food is great and the service is fast - just try to get there early, otherwise you'll have a very long wait to get a table. It gets loud because it's always so busy.

I thoroughly enjoyed this place.  It's not fancy, but the wine and food were great!  We had the paella, grilled calamari, grilled lamb chops, and tuna carpaccio.  For desert we had pears poached in red wine and cream brûlée.  All was excellent and the service was very good.  We will definitely add this restaurant to the rotation!

The food was so good; I ordered the Paella Ibérica, which was both delicious and served in a large skillet. Although I finished all of the paella, it was big enough where I certainly could've taken half of it to go while being totally satisfied with only eating the other half. I highly recommend any paella and any other dishes with fish or dates.

I remember Cafe Iberico being so good that I had it on my list of "must do's" while in Chicago. Unfortunately it did not deliver. Yes it was packed at 7:30pm on a Sunday evening. Both sides of the resultant bustling with lively customers, and we were seated promptly. Yes the service was quite good and you get waters and bread with olive oil right away, but the actual culinary experience was disappointing.  I grew up three years in the Canary Islands, and one year in Madrid, so I am no stranger to delicious Spanish cuisine. We ordered a potpourri of tapas: gambas al ajillo (shrimp in garlic sauce), pulpo con papas fritas (octopus and fries), patatas bravas and jamón ibérico with queso manchego (Spanish ham and manchego cheese). The ONLY dish we loved was the octopus, the shrimp dish was passable and the others were throwaways. We also ordered sangria which was ok, but very very sweet. Nothing about this restaurant was memorable. And the price was expensive considering all the other amazing restaurants where we had eaten this weekend. Clearly it's different types of cuisine, but we ate at The Girl and the Goat, Lou Manatti's and Chicago Diner, and of all the places mentioned, Cafe Iberico was the worst food and the most expensive. We probably won't be returning anytime soon. Three stars for the service, the location (easily accessible to public transportation) and for the octopus dish. Everything else not so good. I would not recommend it.

Wow, can I say the inside of this place completely blew me away. When you first walk in, it looks a little cramped with a tight walkway. But little did I know there was an entire left area, right area, and upstairs. This place was PACKED on a Saturday, which is saying a lot since this place is huge!!! Loved the setting, dim lights and dance music playing in the background that was still playing at a volume where you can hear your friends. I thoroughly enjoyed spending a friend's 23rd birthday here as the food was delightful with delicious flavors and the sangria was flowing throughout our meal. Service was excellent and the place was poppin' towards the end of our meal (9pm). Five stars all around to their Tilapia Entree! Brava!
You can't beat the deliciousness for the prices! If you love Spanish tapas this is the place in Chicago. You will leave happy for about $25 bucks. The Sangria is awesome too.

Went there yesterday Saturday 04/02/2016 had reservations for 16 was a birthday dinner what a mistake I made. Let's start we get to the place 1 minute late our table wasn't ready is ok we didn't mind to wait what really turn me off was the attitude of the hostess she seem annoyed. After a short wait like 10 minutes tops we were seated. Our table was directly next to the bathroom . when I call to confirm , and I did multiple times I mentioned was a birthday dinner I was waiting for something better??. Our waitress was kind of a mess we wait 20 minutes for one beer he was all over the place no too attentive. Food was ok nothing wow some plates had no flavor at all. Not coming back didn't wow us
This place is super fun and festive. Love the high energy vibe and its Totally worth the wait ( which can be long!) Good tapas and great sangria at super reasonable prices.
great tapas, love it! the only problem i that on the weekens the witing time it too long but the foo it great

Terrible service. We sat there for 20 minutes, no one greeted us, or even offered us something to drink. Paid $13 to park for nothing. They werent even busy. I was not the only patron who walked out. Disappointed!

This was definitely a true traditional tapas experience. Food was good, ambience was fantastic and service was great. Definitely most impressed with the desserts (the caramel banana dish was to die for). We ordered the sangria (red) based on other Yelp recommendations and it definitely did not disappoint. The paella was a bit dry, but generous in portion size. The tapas dishes were flavorful. I personally thought it was a bit pricey, but overall a nice experience.

Great place! Excellent to bring out-of-towners or a casual date. Food is great, service is fast, and the atmosphere is fun and festive. Get the red sangria and arrive early. They don't take reservations and the place is always busy; that's a good thing! Oh! And their Patatas Bravas are out of this world; they're made "the important way!"

It is a lively place with busy wait staff.  It is a day later and nothing that I ate was memorable or worth writing about.  The salmon and other appetizers were visually appealing but minimalist. I guess because our group had so much fun talking and catching up with each other the food was secondary.  Will have to try it again to explore the menu more and give it a second shot as well as give the busy wait staff a second shot at being more attentive.

I have gone to this restaurant five times after finding out about it a year ago. I can't sing enough praises about their lamb chops and sangria. I have gone here with parties and had a blast drinking Sangria and being fully content withou breaking the bank. The ambiance of the restaurant is impressive in it own right that it doesn't look manufactured or generated. The food is amazing but not excellent but that being said I have never left here dissatisfied or felt like I was being overcharged for anything. I would highly recommend this restaurant for anyone looking for something casual but that has the feel of a fine dining restaurant.

Went here on a Sunday evening at around 5:30 with a friend and my husband.  We had a really nice meal for a pretty reasonable price, including a bottle of wine.  The food came out pretty quickly.  I'm taking a star away because the waiter was a little bit absent and when we wanted to ask for more bread/water, we couldn't. Everything we had was pretty delicious (most notably the octopus on garlic potatoes).  If you want paella, be sure to order it immediately because it takes a while, but the paella was totally worth the wait and a HUGE portion for a reasonable price.  I was pleased with the experience overall.
Great place to get tapas.  Love the lamb chops, mussels, clams, and fries!  Service is solid.

I used to come here all the time for networking/big group events and I totally forgot about this place. My most recent visit was for a birthday party and there were about 20 of us. Service was very fast and efficient and we ALL enjoyed our food. This is a tapas restaurant so meals are meant to be shared. I had a hard time sharing my spicy potato dish cause it was just too good (so I didn't share) lol. I however did dip my fork into other people's plates and my favorite would have to be the grilled octopus.  Sangria was flowing and I was drinking all of it. They had different flavors to choose from. The food here is delicious and definitely a great place to go with a group.

This is a great place that is hampered by poor service. At this point, if they haven't figured out great service, they probably never will.  First, the amazing - Sangria, especially the red. Just get it. The food - no complaints, the vast majority I really enjoy. Of special note- the patata bravas. The first time i came here, I did not get them as I figured it would be a waste to get potatoes. Don't be me. Get them. The octopus with fries - even if you don't like octopus, you will like these. Trust me. The octopus is grilled, and chopped up into easily bite size pieces, mixed with fries. Worth the try. For service, they need to smooth it out. A few times our forks and plates were taken away, with food still on the way! When the food gets out, we have no way to portion it or even eat it. Asking for the items takes an incredibly long time - 5 or more minutes for plates and forks, while the food gets colder. Skip dessert, there is nothing special there, but definitely bring the family here to impress them (not young kids, though.) Guard your plates and forks.

I used to live in Madrid, so I have tried my fair share of Spanish food. I can say this is honestly one of the most authentic Spanish places I have been to. The food is pretty moderately priced considering the tapas are actually pretty big portions, easily enough for 4 people to share. The patatas bravas were really spicy, not super common in Spain, but good if you like spicy food. Croquetas were good, and tasted similar to what you would get in Spain. I tried the paella and it is also great. It does take a while to cook, so make sure to order enough tapas as apps. Wine is mostly Spanish, and the price per glass is super reasonable.

Came here on a Saturday night and was pleasantly surprised by no wait--the dining area is large, with a bar upstairs.  Grilled octopus: I was pretty confused by how the octopus was mixed in a mound of french fries. The fries were a bit soggy, and the octopus pieces were few and far between. Goat cheese spread: Found this tapa extremely mediocre; while the goat cheese flavors meshed well with the tomato sauce, the marinara itself tasted as if it came from a jar. Grilled shrimp: the one somewhat redeeming tapa of the night. Had a nice amount of spice to it. Overall, the tapas here are larger in size than at a typical tapas place, making it easier to split among larger groups; however, given the quality, I found the food extremely overpriced and underwhelming--in addition to the lackluster tapas mentioned above, the complimentary bread was extremely dry and likely slightly stale. Definitely will not be returning to this place.

We came here with a small group to celebrate a friend's birthday. We were seated an hour after our reservation, which was super uncool. When we were seated, we got sangria which was definitely a highlight of the night! The food overall was just okay. The bread was awful-stale and lacking in any sort of flavor. I found the potatoes boring and the salad very uninspired (it looked like it was dumped straight from a supermarket bag). The goat cheese was also just so so boring. I did like the pork dish with fries that my friend ordered-great flavor there. I found the service to be generally unaccommodating. They would not split the check for us, generally were very stiff, and were clumsy as well. Dishes were placed at the very ends of the table, instead of in the middle, and were then forgotten. Overall-yes to the sangria, and the prices were reasonable, but the service and flavors were lacking. Disappointed.

Though our waiter was attentive one of our ordered items didn't show up until about 20 minutes after the first one. The food was good but not interesting. The spicy potatoes--a large portion--consisted of roasted potato chunks with a thin peppery sauce. No crisp edges, no complex favors. The fried goat cheese was a small piece of liquid cheese swimming in a large amount of tangy tomato sauce with toast rounds arranged around it. We tried two desserts which came in large portions--cinnamon flavored rice pudding and a creme caramel with a thick sugar. Both were simple and tasty.

The owner of this place should be ashamed of serving "something" that they call chorizo, specially charging $10 for a chorizo plate that in reality is low quality sausage. Save yourself some money and get a hot dog at 7/11.

Nothing mind-blowing, but definitely a solid Chicago choice, albeit the location is a bit off-the-beaten track.  The food is good, there are lots of options, and I've had no problem getting a table here without a reservation.  The only real issue I've had is slow service, and the ambiance isn't anything too special.  If you come here, definitely get the goat cheese dish!

We went here on a whim. The negatives were a very loud, busy, and not cozy space. On the positive side, the food was good and I thought the service was great. Our table wobbled, that was fixed immediately. Our waiter made excellent suggestions, and the service was fast. We ordered calamari, octopus&potatos, chorizo, and a goat cheese dish. Everything was very tasty and easy to share with 4 people. For dessert we had the rice pudding and chocolate flan. I prefer a less touristy spot, but this was a decent spot if you are in the area.

Went there with a group from my office for our holiday lunch.  The ambience is just ok but the food is delicious.  We had the patatas bravas, champinones a la plancha, gambas al ajillo, Paella marinera, Paella vegeteriana, and some type of lamb meatballs.  Everything was delicious!  Also had sangria which was good as well although I have had better.  I will definitely visit again.

This is more of a 3.5 star review rounded up to a 4.  I came here late on a Monday night and it was empty. The main dining area was large, so I assume they're used to accommodating a much larger crowd. We were seated immediately and the staff was very attentive.  The food was definitely good, but not spectacular. We had the Gambas Al Ajiilo, Croquetas De Pollo, Calamares a La Plancha, Pulpo a La Plancha, Chorizo y Morcilla, and one chicken dish, but I'm not sure which one it was. I was not bold enough to try the blood sausage, but I enjoyed everything else especially the Croquetas de Pollo. They come with an "Ali-oli" sauce, which was the highlight of my meal. The chicken came with rice that my friend described as "regular rice that they made orange". I didn't have a chance to try it lol.  In addition to all that food, we also ordered three drinks, and the total came out to $96 or $24 each....I can't remember the last time I dined so well for under $25!

After being told the wait time at Au Cheval was a ridiculous 6 hrs, we furiously searched Open Table to see if anything else has last minute availability. Luckily we were able to just walk right in to Cafe Iberico. Ambiance: The main dining area was a huge room packed with tables. Honestly it didn't have that modern or trendy type atmosphere that a lot of places in the area have. No frills decor, which didn't really bother me. I did think that the tables were pretty smushed together to maximize the seating. It was pretty hard to navigate around all the other tables when going to the bathroom.  Service: The service felt just a little bit rushed. We ordered a ton of stuff and were in and out within an hour. It seemed like they just bombarded us plate after plate to the point where there was no space on the table. We had to quickly finish everything on the table to make room for the next dishes. No time for talking haha. I guess I would prefer this though over having to wait long periods if they staggered all the plates. Somewhere in between would've been nice. Food: In true tapas style, we just ordered a ton of different dishes and then got a little taste of each.  Patatas Bravas - This seemed like a more traditional take on patatas bravas than I've seen at other tapas places. It was a huge mound of fried potatoes drenched in a tomato based sauce. The flavor was just ok for me. I did like the slight hint of spice. Also, I was hoping it was less saucy so the potatoes would still be crisp. Quantity wise I was satisfied. Unlike Mercat a la Planxa, we got a full plate of potatoes instead of 5 tater tots on a plate.  Pincho de Solomillo - Basically a skewer of beef and fries and onions. The marinade was pretty flavorful and the meat was juicy. Pretty much like Spanish style steak frites. Queso de Cabra - Pieces of toast spread with some sort of pesto sauce. Then you top it off with a mix of marinara and goat cheese. Loved the crunchy toast mixed with the creamy goat cheese.  Croquetas de pollo - The description said it had chicken and ham in there, but the inside was pretty much had the texture of mashed potatoes and it was hard tell what was in it. Either way, I liked the taste. Crispy outside, smooth filling, and that creamy, cheesy dipping sauce was money. Reminded me of the cheap, street food croquettes I had in Amsterdam. Calamares a la Plancha - Grilled calamari that had a nice smokey, charred flavor off the grill. Texture was a little rubbery and hard to take down.  Empanada - This wasn't what I pictured. Instead of the usual bite sized empanada, it was like huge like a pot pie. Flakey crust filled with beef, veggies, and unfortunately nasty ass raisins haha.   Gambas al Ajillo - Probably one of my favorite dishes of the night. A skillet with shrimp tossed in olive oil, garlic, and some crushed red pepper. Garlic lovers will rejoice about this one.  Raxo adobado - Almost like a pork version of the pincho de solomillo. Pork loin and fries topped with onion/cilantro. The marinade was again tasty but the meat wasn't as tender and juicy as the beef. A little hard to cut through.  Chorizo y Morcilla - Mixed plate of chorizo and blood sausage. The chorizo had a nice crisp skin, but I'm not too big a fan of blood sausage. Wish the portion was a little bigger though.  Overall, dinner was just ok for me. The food was pretty good, with none of the flavors being too memorable. The meal was pretty much all business trying to finish all the food rather than taking our time and enjoying the company. I will say though, for as much food as we ordered, the prices were very reasonable.

It feels like a dive bar in River North. I mean, next to restaurants in the are the front way of Cafe Iberico does not stand out, but when you walk you find yourself in a spacious and beautifully decorated restaurant. It is not fancy; it is great, and economical. Paella plates are huge! Good size for two hungry people. Delicious tapas with octopus and, of course, olives (just like in Spain, delicious!)! And sangria is great!

This place is very trendy and popular.  Every time I have been here, it has been packed!  I must say though the food is not worth the price if you are a fan of spicy.  I would not bring a date here as the noise is pretty loud!

Enjoyed the sangria here, but the food was just so-so. The patatas bravas were too spicy, and the croquetas were unremarkable. The best thing we ordered was one of the specials: goat cheese wrapped in eggplant with tomato sauce. Noise level at 9 pm was fine and suitable for a date.
Food is good but not great. The paella had an off taste. Portions were so so. Atmosphere mediocre. Wait staff was good. Would try it again but in the evening not noon.

My favorite Spanish restaurant outside of Spain. This is the "real deal"! Authentic and delicious! The menu is expansive and the daily specials are always excellent. I have eaten at Café Iberico on at least 20 different occasions, and it has ALWAYS exceeded expectations. Although everything on the menu is delicious, the Pulpo Gallego is especially good, and the best I have ever had, including Spain. The wine list is equal to the food, and has a great range of prices/choices---from very well chosen inexpensive bottles of wine with a great quality to price ratio, to world class high end bottles. This is one of the best food and drink buys in the city of Chicago. A "must" if you've never been. And, for me, it is an almost required stop every time I am in Chicago.
Very authentic tapas.  Love the octopus and spicy potatoes!  This place has been totally yummy for many years. Highly recommended!

Ive being coming here for over 15 years. Loud, fun, delicious food, very affordable. This was always our pit stop before going out. Come early or be ready to wait for a while on Fridays and Saturdays.

This place is okay for a pretty satisfying, yet economical, fairly easy meal. It is not as good as I remember from about a dozen years ago.  Again prices are economical and being tapas and pintxos, great variety.  But, the decor is dated. And the server (I was at the tapas bar) was having a hard time keeping it together and didn't know the menu all that well.  As for food quality, it's pretty decent. Difficult to screw up tapas. But, I'd say Cafe Ba-Ba-Re-Ba's food is better these days. The beef skewers, though, no good.  Overall, tapas first-timers will probably be satisfied here and the pricing suits families.

The food and fruit wine was great, there are many seafood in the fried rice as you can see. And they have a bar where you can order some entries. Every time I went here, there are so many people. I guess people love here. Also, they provide olive oil for bread. The waiters are professional. Hope to be here again.
Delicious food. My aunt who's from Madrid always chooses to come here and after coming back from Spain I can say that this is very authentic.

This is my favorite tapas place in Chicago! I would recommend you make reservations, because it does get busy on weekend nights.  We usually get the sangria pitchers (really good!), and usually get at least 2 of the grilled octopus tapa.  This is my favorite one on the menu.  I've tried their paella, and it takes a while to cook... and not especially good- I'd stick with the tapas.  There are so many tapas to choose from- I don't think I've tried a bad one yet.

Been here a couple of times. Tapas style food. It's great. Recommend it to anyone looking for either a cute date or a small group outing.  Staff is very accommodating, atmosphere is inviting, and drinks are great! Definitely recommend trying the goat cheese dip and the garlic shrimp (I forget the exact name).
I loved this place. Their food is amazing and the prices are not so bad. It's a great place to watch soccer games.

I have visited Iberico over a handful of times and the experience keeps getting progressively worse. Sigh! The service is pretty clueless and the food is just tasteless. If I order 8 tapas, I will allow two of them to be mediocre or even bad but if 7 out of 8 are bad then I am going to be disappointed. We had the goat cheese bake, octopus, Russian potatoes, chicken and rice skewers, some spicy potatoes with red sauce, tuna among others. Tuna was okay and the bake wasn't bad but the bread that came with it was awful. The food tasted really old and microwaved.  The only reason this review has 2 stars is the sangria. But as far as food goes I will take my appetite to baba reebas if I crave tapas again.

This is my favorite tapas place in Chicago. My fiancé and I have been coming here for years to celebrate bday parties, anniversaries or just anything. It's the perfect place to be...Always great food, great sangria, great service and hardly ever have to wait.  Must try the baked goat cheese, gambas al ajillo, and pulpo a la plancha...it's a little bit pricey but definitely worthy! I think they also have weekly specials on other cold and hot tapas.

Really cute spanish restaurant. Perfect for a date or to go after a long day for some tapas and a pitcher sangria with friends. Good spanish atmosphere and music ( my husband said its latin not spanish but i liked it) we shared tapas and a paella because it is really much. As dessert we had the platano with caramel this was really delicious. I really recomment this restaurant, but i missed the ailoi woth the bread like in spain. The price is not cheap , but for the service and food absolutly okay

Went here on a Saturday night with a small group. Our rez was at 6 so the place was starting to get busy. The hosts seemed a little harried with seating people and managing large parties coming in. They were pleasant enough, but a bit abrupt and unsure? Hard to describe but it was a minor point. Also, in the lobby area, there is case along the bar in which each tapas dish is sampled. Kinda like in the mall where they have sample dishes on display. It was odd and not very visually appealing. We were seated quickly upstairs and served drinks quickly. The menu is large, and has photos of each item. Honestly, the photos were not that appetizing and kinda made the menu overwhelming to read. Most of the items are things typically on tapas menus. We ordered: spicy potatoes, fried calamari, grilled shrimp, goat cheese/crostini, mixed meat/seafood paella, chorizo, garlic mushrooms, and clams. All of the food was fine, but that's it. The best dish was probably the mushrooms, but they could have used a little more salt.   For the record, this is the largest tapas restaurant I've ever been to.  Most places I've been are tiny (and more expensive), but the food at those places was more complex and flavorful. I think this place does really well in terms of volume - our party of 7 seemed to be the smallest group in there. The servers were attentive and friendly which is always great. In the end, we each paid about $16 (not including drinks), so it's reasonably priced in general. But the food was bland so I don't think I'd come here again unless someone was hosting a party.
Good food! A little pricier than yelp rated it, but good. Very popular spot. Service was pretty quick despite the huge crowd. Very loud inside, which was less ideal, but not a deal breaker.

My wife and I love Cafe Iberico. First of all is location, it is right in the middle of downtown Chicago. While the street parking can be challenging, they do offer valet which is nice.  The interior is very authentic. You feel like you're in Barcelona with the decorations, music, crowds, and very cozy (cramped) seating. While we enjoy it for a tapas restaurant, be aware intimate quiet conversations are not possible. Nonetheless, the food is top notch. We love the spicy potatoes, goat cheese dish, meat platter, mussels, and sauteed mushrooms. Pretty much all of the tapas are excellent. The only reason I do not give this restaurant 5 stars is I do agree that at times the paella leaves a bit to be desired. Sometimes it is excellent and others only so-so. I must say though, this restaurant is always loaded with customers who certainly by the cheers for the soccer teams on TV appear to be from Spain. That to me is always a very good sign.

My favorite place to eat in Chicago.  Great food, great atmosphere , and great service.  All of the dishes are very tasty.   Ask the waiter about items off the menu which tend to be great dishes.   Must try!!!

Their hot tapas selection is pretty good but I would've liked to see some stuffed mushrooms in there.  The Paella is to die for we've had the vegetarian and the seafood paella and they are both incredible. Get the Sangria pitcher to share and enjoy the night!

Went here with a couple of coworkers and was satisfied, but not much more. The spicy potato dish was great. We had a shrimp in garlic sauce dish that was also really good. The chicken paella was the part of the meal that I was most excited about but was the biggest let down. It was like they rolled out a pan of Uncle Bens rice and tried to pass it off a Spanish tradition. Terrible.  The service was good but I will definitely be taking my business to another tapas place next time I'm in the mood for Spanish food.

Came here with a friend a few weeks ago.  Huge selection of tapas...EVERYONE can find something.  Portions are good for the money.  Not too much food, but enough to enjoy each dish.  Ordered four dishes for two people and was more than enough.  Also have great sangrias! If you go on a Saturday evening, prepare to sit at the bar and wait or wait awhile for a table...however, it is worth the wait.

Really good food and fast service. Nice atmosphere and family friendly, as well. We are very satisfied with the flavor and spice level. We recommend it. Not a whole lot around the area but it's a good destination and then walking to Navy pier is about 30 minutes.

I absolutely love this place. Delicious tapas and sangria! A couple of my favorite tapas here: datiles con jamon, patatas ali-oli, patatas bravas, pincho de solomillo, queso de cabra, and pulpo a la plancha. This is a great place for a party because the restaurant has a lot of seating and the service is great! You can't beat these cheap tapas!
My favorite Tapas place in Chicago. Delicious, but reasonably priced. Must try octopus dish + french fries!
Really, really good spot! The lamb chop special is the way to go. Stop after hearing that.
food is yummy here and the price is acceptable.Plus, service is good.Wonderful experience!

The best, and best priced, seafood paella!  Wow - I visit here every trip to Chicago, if possible, and they never disappoint.  Not once.   All the dishes I've tried here are well above average in taste; each fresh, flavorful and prepared the way they are supposed to be.  The service is consistently professional.  The prices make it even better. Tiramasu and flan are great.  A bunch of nice wines.  Flavorful, strong coffee.

Very disappointing experience.  After years of coming here, I went to Cafe Iberico last night and it was so bad that I will never come back again.  The prices have increased once again and honestly it is completely overpriced.  My friend ordered a beef skewer with fries when really it was a onions fries and a tiny piece of beef.  I got the patatas bravas and they tasted nothing like the ones I've had before.  I also got the croquetas and I bit into a bone and the flavor just not there.  The service was also bad.  The waiter didn't bring all my food because he "thought I didn't want the rest"...  This place has increased prices and decreased everything else where it's no longer what it used to be. Going to Babareeba from now on
I love this place. Every chance I get it, going into the city. I plan on eating here.  This place needs to open another location in Oak Brook.  I would be there 4x a month. Lol
Cafe Iberico is one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago!  Perfect for big groups or small get togethers, everything on the menu is fantastic.  Pitchers of sangria and amazing paella, yes please!

True Tapas Bar. I have always wanted to go to a tapas bar because back where I'm from, most places call themselves tapas, but charge like they're full dishes. No one understands what a tapas bar really is.... At any rate, this place was phenomenal, very crowded, very noisy, but very worth it. I ordered a few hot and a few cold plates and they all were great. Presentation was nice, our server made sure to stagger the plates so we could really enjoy each individual tapas. I wish I had a place like this back in my hometown but sadly, this will be a treat only when I visit Chicago.

We used to love this place - but that was a long time ago. We went there recently because it was very late, and our late-night options were limited. The place has changed, and not for the better. It was crowded, noisy, and the food was really mediocre (it used to be crowded and noisy with good food). Bacon-wrapped dates, supposedly filled with goat cheese, arrived on a plate with a tasteless orange sauce, and a mound of rice pilaf in the center. The dates had a mushy texture, and the rice (included mainly to make it look as if you were getting more for your money) was bland. My husband's grilled squid was okay, but nothing fantastic. Tomato bread with Manchego cheese and Spanish ham was good, though the bread was soggy. A plate of Morcilla y Chorizo had a stingy two pieces of Morcilla (blood sausage), and the rest was mostly inedible (fatty and tough) Spanish chorizo. Either the Morcilla is a lot more expensive, or they assumed no one would really want to eat it, hence the skimpy portion. The worst, most disappointing thing we ordered, however, was the seafood, pork and chicken paella - it was as bland as the "Spanish" rice you get at a Mexican restaurant - no, I take that back - it was much more bland that that. There wasn't a hint of the paprika that usually enlivens a good paella. The shrimps were tiny dried things (there may have been three of them in the whole pan). The whole mess was liberally sprinkled with peas and chopped red pimentos, which added no flavor at all. The Sangria was okay, and that's about it. Next time we want tapas, we'll go a little farther south, to Mercat a la Planxa.
The food is always on point and the server this time was really good. I come here all the time. Definitely rate this number 1 in Chicago for tapas.

Tapas joint in River North.  Reasonably priced, and everything was delicious!  My friend and I ordered four small plates to share between the two of us and ended up having way too much food--we honestly would have been fine with one apiece.  While the chicken empanada and baked goat cheese were definitely very tasty, they weren't much to write home about. The true stars were the potatoes bravas (be still, my heart) and the sangria--oh man, the SANGRIA. We had white wine sangria--a little untraditional for November, perhaps, but it was light and not overly sweet and just wonderful.  Would absolutely go back if I was in the neighborhood!

I gotta start with saying that I've been coming here for the longest time probably four to five years and so far I've never had a bad experience definitely the steak with the potato cubes with the dressing gravy sorta like is unbelievably delicious not exactly carb friendly but hey if you don't care about carbs you have to try that dish it also comes with asparagus on the side which is a great touch sangria with the apples inside is delicious  its one of the best sangria I've tried
Perfect place, nice people, spanish food!!! Everything perfect. Normal price, according 100% with quality!
Yummy! We go here for work events, baby showers, birthdays, any excuse to get out of the office!  The service is always friendly, and quick.  The garlic shrimp and spicy potatoes are #1.

Great servers, bartenders and food! I love tapas and this restaurant does not disappoint. Everything is flavorful and cooked to perfection. The bar can mix up anything you'd like but try the sangria first!The decor is not too fancy, but you'll be comfortable. If you're looking for authentic Spanish food in Chicago this place is for you.

2 stars for the server but 3 for the food. He took forever to come back and seem uninterested in taking care of us. The busboy was actually more nicer and started a conversation with us, he was very funny and nice. ( He gets a 5 star of course )

Not thrilled with this place. Came last night for a girls dinner with 8 of the gal friends. We arrived at 7pm on a Saturday evening and didn't have any trouble getting a table right away. We were seated upstairs in the main portion of the restaurant, which was still pretty empty at 7pm. I wasn't impressed with their dining space. No decor to speak of, essentially just a very large room with long rectangular tables. Their dining furniture is beat up. Also, no music at all. As the restaurant got more crowded, it became clear that the acoustics in the room were extremely poor; we were shouting to talk to the person right beside us (and again, not because any music). I ordered the scallops a la plancha, bacon wrapped dates, and patatas bravas. The food was interesting... I've had tapas many times and none of the flavors were familiar or like other tapas dishes I've had before. The bacon wrapped dates and the scallops were both served with rice side dishes. The scallops were cut into thin slices, which changes the concept of biting into a scallop, as there was no depth to these guys. The patatas bravas were like blanched potatoes in sauce. No sort of crispiness, instead they were soft potatoes in a runnier sauce. And finally, the bacon wrapped dates were dense and small.  Our waiter was in a rush and didn't introduce himself. Just came by as quickly as possible to take our orders and leave. At one point, the wrong dish was dropped off at our table and the waiter said we could just eat this instead and then asked if he could cancel the original order we had placed for the other dish. Unprofessional.  I will say that the $18 and up bottles of wine at this place are quite redeeming. We enjoyed lots of wine and sangria and left with a bill under $30 each, so that was the win of the evening.  Bottom line: I would not opt to come here again unless it was for the inexpensive wine list.

Got engaged here and then after we got married at the court house we came back for a celebratory meal. The food is amazing- I'm obsessed with the dates- and I love love love the white wine sangria. The staff is also super friendly and the watches the is beautiful. This is kind of my family's new go to nice restaurant in the city.  Although the prices are a little high you get a ridiculous amount of food for your money- the tapas plates are more like dinner plates- so id say go with five people or more. My favorite dishes are the spicy potatoes and the chorizo plate. Also don't skip the flan.

I've had better tapas stateside at multiple places in SF and Washington DC. We ordered: Pulpo a la Plancha - decent; I've had better. Paella - Again.. decent but I've had way better. Seafood needed to be fresher and there was no socarrat on the bottom.  Salad - pretty decent It came with a stale bread basket and mediocre and lacking service. Like Smoque BBQ; another Yelp listing that was highly rated that led us astray.

Arrived in the early evening on a Saturday, and had to sit at the bar because apparently every table was booked. For anyone familiar with authentic Spanish tapas, the notion of making reservations to eat tapas has got to seem a bit silly. It is supposed to be a very casual, low key way to eat. Anyway, the food was ok, if not awe-inspiring, the staff was friendly, and the restaurant was nice. That said, portions are smaller compared to the authentic tapas, and maybe we were there on a bad night, but items were very slow to come out of the kitchen. Had octopus, bacon wrapped dates, calamari good, not overcooked, but not spectacular either, and the goat cheese in tomato sauce was fine. If you ask for their signature tapa (jamon Iberico), they give you a cheap salty serrano ham instead. I asked to see the Iberico ham package (leg) but they refused. I liked everything that we ordered, even though there was not much of it. Some of the pickled things were so tiny and minuscule they were a waste of mouth energy just chewing. Maybe this is a fun place to go when someone else is paying; it is a pretty poor value considering all we had were drinks and some small items.  We might have ordered something else, but the kitchen was so slow neither of us wanted to wait another 45 minutes for a small plate of sausages or gambas. Four or five stars are beyond me. I have a problem when we, a party of two are over $100 and several plates into our meal and aren't even remotely half full. The service was good, but we got the look of "that's it?" when we decided to cut our losses short and stopped ordering dishes.  I've been to Spain, I know what tapas should be, and sure some items were appetizing but barely enough to share.  I'm embarrassed to say that we stopped ordering, walked out hungry and continued to walk until we got to "Fogo de Chão Brazilian Steakhouse"... at the other end of the strip and had a second dinner and much more satisfying. If you feel like blowing money, do yourself a favor spend 5 bucks at the taco place. Then throw the rest of your money in the air and wave bye bye to it. I guarantee you that it will make you feel better than throwing your money here. I'm not a cheap skate, I know good food and I also know when I'm getting ripped off and the flavors are not astounding.

I hadn't been here for some time. What was I thinking!!? I forgot how delicious their sangria was , there's just nothing like it anywhere!  Their papatas bravas are the best I've ever had and ive been to Spain.. So I can say that having had tasted the different varieties of patatas straight from their origin. They're probably doing it all wrong here but who cares! So many delicious dishes to talk about them all. Queso de cabra is also one of my faves. I suppose I should say that I always hear good things about the shrimp but I really don't care for them. They have the seafood smell and taste like they're old or haven't been washed, and the fact that they're not deveined is kind of a turn off for me ..gag.. All in all, the sangria just takes away any negative opinion you might have of this place.  Cheers!

There are much better places to eat in River North. Don't waste your time here. When you first walk in, it smells like a fish market. Luckily the dining area doesn't smell, but the fish market smell is not appetizing at all. On a Saturday night, the paellas take over an hour to make. Why would I come to a restaurant to wait over an hour for half the items on the menu? I might as well save money and make something at home in less than an hour. The best thing I tried is the spicy potatoes. Please don't order any dishes with shrimp. Their shrimp is disgusting! The shrimp they serve is probably the source of the fish market smell when you walk in. There are a few restaurants in Chicago that don't source their shrimp from fresh sources, and this is one of them. I don't think they cleaned the guts out of the shrimp before cooking. I thought the octopus was ok, but the others in my party didn't like it. The chicken also wasn't appetizing. The atmosphere was also very loud and it was very hard for my party to carry on a conversation. The service was also slow. I don't know why this place has such good reviews, because there are so many other places in the area that are much better.
Great place!! Food is outstanding. Love coming here. If your a seafood eater try the mussels! Even when they have been busy, they are quick to seat you.
This tapas restaurant is so good! My go-to are the croquetas de pollo, mussels, clams, grilled calamari, and the shrimp. The paella iberico is also delicious.

this place is great !!! But very loud on the second floor ! The first floor is the best place to sit ! I would highly recommend the potatoes Bravas ! They are spicy but so good !!!  and the calamari is also a must !

I like this place! The sangria is tasty, great wine selection and their food is delicious. The portion sizes are not small in comparison to other tapas places. one thing that they have to take care is about customer services, especially host and management , came here couple time and both are so rude, don't even smile or said hello..  other than that you just can't go wrong with Cafe' Iberico!
The food and dessert was really good. I wasn't too fond of the poor lighting because it was hard to read my menu but we adjusted. The staff was really nice and paid a lot of attention to us.

Girlfriend and I got hungry late (around 11 PM) and found this place on yelp. Service staff was really friendly, helpful and took care of us. Had the grilled veggies and seared scallops. Both were very tasty and we'll be back to try other items!

The price to food quality&quantity ratio is unbeatable.  We started with a seafood salad that came piled on a large dinner plate.  All the seafood items were super tender and yummy.  We also go their grilled octopus with potatoes dish which I almost sent back because it had the consistency of super tender chicken - I could not believe it was octopus!  It is a must try.  Their paella had great flavor but it  was way too oily for my taste so I would not try that again but that might be a personal preference issue so I won't knock them for it.  They also have a decent wine selection that starts at just $25 a bottle which is a great price! The venue could benefit from some acoustic insulation.  It was incredibly loud in there and also very crowded.  Our server was frazzled and out of breath most of the time so the service mediocre. All in all the food was incredible and I'm looking forward to trying out more dishes there.

Smells like blood sausage when you walk in, it stays on your clothes and hair. Food, no big deal. It should smell great when you come in the doors to make you hungry. We were rushing to leave. Should have went to Dagwoods at least there we leave satisfied and smelling like good charcoal grill. LOL.

It has been more than a decade (maybe two?) since I've eaten here last. Doesn't look like a thing has changed. No reason to change those delicious sangrias or tasty chicken legs on the bone. Both are delicious. In fact, many of the tapas were prepared well, I really enjoyed the food. The service was decent as well. That said, the music was far too loud to have a decent conversation. A shame because we would have stayed longer and had an after dinner drink. The place could also use an update, the 1980's charm is beginning to fade.

Our server gave me back my receipt but did not return my credit card. When asked he quickly found the "lost" credit card however when I asked the front host for a comment card they apparently dont have any. When I asked for the manager I was told he  was busy. Quite disappointing that they would make such a mistake and think it was no big deal be careful of their lax service. Also note: their paella is one of the outliers and worst dishes I have ever had. Also the free bread is cold and tough. fyi, their seafood is delicious.  Best of luck when visiting this establishment.

So good solid Spanish tapas.   But they have a discriminatory policy - men are not allowed in wearing a tank top (even though it was above 90 that day) yet women can.  Too bad - we walked to a well known upscale restaurant near by and had no problem getting in and spending our money.

We were so disappointed by last night's dinner.  Cafe Iberico is a long-term favorite whenever we are in Chicago.  Starting circa 1990, we have enjoyed many wonderful tapas and celebrated anniversaries, birthdays,  holidays and get together with family and friends, pleased with great service, incredible food and reasonable prices.  Last night's experience was different.  My ensalada mixta was wilted and soggy.  Was it leftover from the day before?  The pulpo a la plancha, one of our all time favorites, was definitely not up to par, dry and rubbery, drowned in a sea of french fries instead of gently nestled on a bed of fries as we remember.  Even the paella was relatively tasteless.  There are other good tapas in the area. Sadly, I think we'll be looking elsewhere next time.

I know I tend great restaurants highly but I tend to go to great restaurants! Iberico is a Chicago landmark in the tapas world. If this is what you are looking for then in Chicago this is where to go. Trust the staff recommendations. Enjoy!

This is a really solid tapas place in Near North.  The food is really solid.  I've been here a few times with a group, so I've been able to try a variety of the different hot and cold tapas plates.  One of my favorites is the potatoes with the spicy sauce.  Those are amazing.  Really, I have liked the vast majority of their tapas plates.  The staff and waiters were very attentive and friendly too. Why am I docking 1 star (if I could, I'd probably dock 1.5 stars)?  When you first walk in, there is a horrible, musty smell that just doesn't put you in the best eating mood.  It's because the kitchen is located adjacent to the entrance.  Also, the interior is pretty dated.  Finally, I was not overly impressed with the sangria.  The first time I went there it tasted extremely watered down.  The other times I have tried it, it tasted better, but I was expecting a lot more since I had heard such great things about their sangria. In terms of the food  and staff, they get 5 stars,   I just wish they could somehow remodel and move the location of their kitchen.  I also wish their sangria was a little stronger.

This place is not bad, but not great. To start, ambiance feels a little food court-like, and it is very loud; definitely not romantic. Our waiter was very pleasant, attentive, and seemed well versed in the menu. We got the seafood paella, the whole reason we went, and it was ok, but nothing special. We also had a couple tapas, some croquettes and the goat cheese/tomato/bread, both of which were pretty tasty. I'd recommend sticking to the tapas.

Delightful. The food is always top notch and tastes extra amazing. Make sure to try the patatas bravas and pincho de pollo. Why not 5 stars?! Their space plan could be improved, people are bumping into people; it can become uncomfortable at times. Nonetheless, I will battle the crowds if it means I can have delicious food with great customer service!

I sought out a Spanish restaurant for dinner because I was craving paella and this one claims to be the largest and most authentic outside of Spain. The interior is homey--nice, but not fancy. We went a little early because they don't take reservations and it was mostly families there. We got a nice table by the window and service was efficient, if not overly personable.  We started by sharing a cazuela de carne: slow roasted beef with potatoes and carrot in a clay pot. We were really hungry and this comfort food made our mouths and tummies so happy! The beef was meltingly tender as were the vegetables and it all had so much flavor. That is a dish I will crave again on a cold night in the future.  We then shared a seafood paella which was good, but didn't match up to what I've eaten in Barcelona. The rice got a bit crusty around the edges (here, a good thing), but not in the bottom of the pan so was a bit one-note texturally. It had nice saffron color and flavor though. The seafood wasn't as plentiful as I would have wished, but it was a pretty good dish overall.  We were originally interested in ordering and sharing multiple tapas, but this isn't really the place for that unless you have a large party. Each tapa is larger and more expensive than would be practical for 2 people to share--think "family style" side dish portion.  I would go back in a heartbeat for more of the cazuela de carne and think it would also be a good place to come with a large family or group of friends to share the large tapas dishes.
Definitely my favorite place in Chicago to go to eat! Love it every time I go there. Most delicious food!

Highlight of the review: Gluten Free Menu.  We finally visited the place after having it bookmarked for a while now. A great to enjoy family n friends.  Highly recommend: spicy potatoes, paella, grilled octopus and shrimp in garlic oil dipping.

Not too much to say about this place. We walked in with a group of 5 but we were not seated due to their dress code not allowing the tank top one of our group was wearing.  Nothing wrong with jeans, trashy tshirts, or anything along those lines. But no tank tops. They did offer us a t-shirt - 2 sizes too small that was trahsier looking than the tank top.  Cafe Iberico - get off your high horse. You're not nearly classy enough to be enforcing an idiotic dress code.

Ahhmazing, tapas to sangria everything is super good! Will continue to come back. We always order the patatas bravas, a paella, queso de cabra, and sangria. I've been for casual dinners and for birthdays and professional  meetings. And a bonus they are open late!!
Best tapas I eat ( in Chicago ).  The size / portion are good + I gave only 4 stars because of: A) bread is not fresh! B) olive oil should be "olive oil" and not vegetable oil

The food was really tasty and the service was fast and polite. I recommend the grilled octopus with fries and the spicy potatoes. The paella Marinera which is seafood on rice is a huge portion so you can share that among three people. The problem with this place, for me, is that it's really loud. It's really hard to enjoy your food when you have groups of people shouting around you. This is not a romantic place. It's more of a group place.

Me and my boyfriend went here on a Friday night for date night. First thing I noticed: it was packed! However, we were still seated quickly which I appreciated. Next thing I noticed: it was incredibly loud. Me and my BF found it difficult to even talk from across the table, since it was so loud. If you enjoy a more lively, louder crowd, this place it great. If you enjoy a quitter, more intimate/romantic place, skip this restaurant. Moving on the service, our waiter explained the menu and then disappeared for about 20mins, we eventually asked a busboy to find him and bring him back because we were staving and ready to order! The great thing was, once we finally ordered, our food and drinks arrived in less than 10 minutes! The sangria was excellent, it's prepared very traditionally and was an excellent complement to the meal. Next, the food. We had three tapas. It was difficult to choose because everything in the menu looked great! The tapas range from about $8-$13, I found these prices reasonable for the quality of the food (although don't expect large portions, it's tapas, after all). The calamari was very good! Not the best I've ever had, but it was fresh and delicious. Next we had pinchos de pollo, grilled chicken on a stick served with saffron rice and caramelized onions. This was excellent. It reminded me of food I had in Puerto Rico it tasted incredibly fresh, we both loved this dish. Lastly we had grilled octopus served over sliced potatoes. I would avoid this dish. The potatoes has literally no seasoning or sauce whatsoever, making the dish very bland. Even though the octopus still seemed fresh, the overall taste of the dish was super disappointing, especially when compared to the quality of the other two dishes. Overall, it was fun to try a tapas place and the quality of ingredients at this restaurant is top notch. If you do decide to visit, make sure to get the sangria and be prepared for a routy crowd!

Alert: our credit card was skimmed by staff here. We have used this card twice this year so the theft was easy to trace. It happens and I do not entirely blame the restaurant. BUT when we called to report it the manager was less than interested and seemed confused by the entire matter. She said the owner would get back to us. That never happened. Well, your waiter and his friend got gas, shoes and haircuts. Food and drink were great, as always - but I will never return.

Like the paellas; the tapas are good. The restaurant gets very busy and loud; the last couple of times I went, they didn't have music playing which made the noise very noticeable. One time I went there the table wasn't very stable, we had to use a lot of napkins to stabilize it. I went there few times, I don't prefer to go there. If you're craving paellas/tapas and prefer to stay in the RiverNorth/Gold Coast areas, then you can check out this place, other wise I don't recommend. You won't get anything unique or special at this place, every thing is about average including environment, food, and customer service.
Love the food here. With friends and had several small plates, including chorizo, mussels, salmon, vegetarian paella, mushrooms. Good service too.

I've been coming here a couple of times a year for getting on maybe 20 years. Tonight was disappointing. The service was great, but the kitchen is falling flat.  Flavored that used to astound, now whimper. Dishes are unbalanced, cooked and prepared to be bland, mass production, and uninteresting. Iberico's chef was legend; putting all the competition in place. Now he has become tame and happy with the middle of the road.  I hope that this was just a bad day and not an example of the downfall of a once great restaurant.

I'd been twice a decade ago and it was much better. This time there was a really strong, musty smell that permeated the place and frankly made it hard to enjoy the food.  Sad, because this has previously been my favorite place to eat in Chicago.

I was looking forward to having a great dining experience here and after having dined at other tapas bars in the city I was expecting a lot from this highly ranked restaurant.  The sangría is very smooth and some of the dishes are fantastic, but something about being crammed into a room full of people on a weekday evening makes the meal a bit less enjoyable. The server was fantastic, he was attentive and helpful, but the ambiance of the place does not compare to other places. I was content with my food but the whole experience at Ibérico did not live up to the hype about it. Maybe next time. Maybe I'll get better seating and choose a new set of dishes.

Went in on a Saturday evening around 10, so finding a seat was no trouble at all. We started off with a pitcher of red sangria, which was pretty good, although I'm used to sangria that has a little brandy in it. We had the baked goat cheese as a starter, and the sauce was simple and flavorful, the way it's supposed to be. I had a special, a grilled skewer of lamb, cooked medium rare, once again, the way I requested it; it was served with Israeli couscous, and everything was delicious. I had a perfectly decent Manhattan for after dinner, and I tried a little of my date's flan, which was spot on and not too sweet. Overall, the atmosphere was a little louder than I prefer, and my date almost got trampled by a drunken bride to be at her bachelorette's party, but that's no fault of the restaurant.

These tapas aren't small. These were almost 1/3 of an a entrée size. So beware of that. The wine selection from Spain was excellent and I really enjoyed the very dry red wines myself. Best foods:  seafood paella, octopus and the grilled squid. Oh yeah, the spicy potatoes were surprisingly great! The seating was excellent and the service was spot on.

Why have I never reviewed this place, I've been here MANY times over the years. This is a place that's good for a big group. When you get the inevitable giant bill, it's not a big deal to split it, as you are probably dining on shared tapas. Reasonable prices, and the sangria keeps flowin'. It's gotten a little big, but if you are looking for a racous, loud, relatively authentic Spanish experience, this is probably a good choice.

Have you been to Tapas Valencia in South Loop? Cafe Iberico might have been five stars years ago, however I feel like they still are busy because people don't know any better. The restaurant must be riding on these coattails.  The food was good, however in comparison to other Tapas joints, it just fell below the standards they have set.  Portions are not large for price, quality of food was so so... I would come back here, but only if it was extremely convenient. Even then, a few extra miles to Tapas Valencia will still be worth it.
Got the Iberico paella for lunch from a client recently and loved it! Great food and awesome portions

If anyone hasn't had Spanish Tapas before, I really suggest going to this place because of the abundance of dishes available. Veggie dishes are very limited but I really liked the idea of hot and cold tapas along with entrees with chicken/seafood and desserts. The place was jam-packed on a thursday evening (but it was long weekend). The service was a little slow but decent. We ordered the patatas bravas as appetizer, chicken empanada and veggie empanada and cazula de pollo( chicken drumsticks with potatoes). The patatas bravas was spicy potatoes -  they were really good. The empanadas were soo big enough to share among two people as an appetizer. Chicken empanada was good and heard veggie one was good.  FYI: Entree had just one veggie option. So my friend ordered one more empanada. The drumstick with potatoes were soo heavy - there were 6 pcs of chicken that was good and potatoes were pretty much same as bravas. Heavy stuff :)
Delicious food and beautiful ambience.  Yummiest tapas I've ever had.  Must go back for the sangria!
Went there for lunch today, first time tried tapas and really enjoyed it. The dates wrapped in ham was the group favorite. A new and good experience.

Good tapas place down in river north, I'll be back soon for sure. If you've been to Cafe Ba Ba Reeba, that's what I'll compare Iberico against. To start, if you're flying solo, the bar seems pretty cool. They have smaller tapas fit for a single person, given the portions of the normal tapas, this might not be a bad idea if you're with a small group looking to try a bunch of different stuff. The quality/presentation wasn't as good as Ba Ba Reeba, but overall, we really enjoyed our orders! The portions are pretty big for tapas, our group did not leave hungry (7 tapas between 3 people). I'd recommend the scallops and garlic shrimp, the shrimp were our favorites by far! We also really enjoyed the beef and chicken skewers. We ordered all tapas right away, not realizing how fast everything would come out from the kitchen. Our table was packed immediately. I would highly recommend spacing it out, only placing a few orders in at a time. Overall, great time, good food, decent service. I look forward to heading back soon.

I went here with a bunch of coworkers the other night and were easily accommodated. The servers were friendly and attentive. The food was absolutely delicious. Every plate that came out was better and better. The sangria was great too. Loved it!

Awesome food as always. They have quick service, good sangria and yummy food. We got the garlic shrimp, tilapia with beans and Rapini, chicken brasa, lamb and chicken pixtos. All the dishes were delicious.  A highly recommended place

The reason for 2 stars is that I love the food but I have been there prob 5 times and 4/5 times the waiter/waitress was horrible!! Very slow, don't know the menu really well and also our food took forever.

Can't go wrong with this place. Plenty of seating in main and upper levels with good food. Paella dishes are about $14-15 and will fill you up. My other favorite dish is their goat cheese and tomato sauce served with garlic roasted bread. You cannot go wrong with the goat cheese dish (not the salad!). They also usually feature some sort of drink special so those are fun to take advantage of.

Love love love this place. It is so neat how the tapas are all brought out in the dish they were cooked in. Love the white sangria. Great place for a light or heavy bite. The staff is always very accommodating.

Ok so this place has great ratings on yelp so I made a point of going there during my last trip to Chicago last week. I have to say I was not impressed.  The food was OK, nothing amazing at all. It is a casual place. I got the seafood Paella and it was just really OK.  The shrimp with garlic was good but again nothing too amazing. But the worst part is the smell of the place. When you first walk in there is a horrible smell in the hallway. Really not good at all. Thank god the dinning area did not smell but the front entrance smell was horrible. Not sure why but I will not be returning.

First time having tapas and apparently this is the place to go. Loved everything I had, goat cheese and garlic shrimp where the highlights. Sangria was fresh and not too strong. The atmosphere was warm and family style. Will be back for sure.

Food was good, although the tapas' portions were too large (which defeats the purpose as tapas bars are fun when you want to try many different dishes). The ambiance is loud, which makes the place ideal for larger groups, less for date night. Service was good (tapas come out very quick so you could have a quick dinner). Final bill was higher than I expected.

Lamb Chop with fennel and potatoes cooked in an earthen pot, so delicious. A must have at Cafe Iberico and don't forget their Sangria. The best part of the meal, their desserts. Needless to say one of the best tapas place in the city. They have Ample sitting areas  #chicagofoodhop #cafeiberico

I ordered takeout emañada for a special occasion.  The girl on the phone was completely unable to explain or understand my order. When i got there 45 minute later to pick them up, what I saw was completely not what I ordered.  And they were not ready.  I cancelled my order and had to go to a deli to pick up a substitute for my party.   I hope the takeout phone-order person can be trained better in the future so that customers don't leave empty handed and disappointed like I did
ONE WORD "AMAZING" Not pricey Good atmosphere Amazing Sangria Food is delicious

This place was recommended to me by a friend. The duck, shrimp, and paella is by far my favorites. Great Spanish food and definitely one of my go to places when I visit Chicago! The sangria is also really really good! Not too sweet, but also not bitter.  If you're not paying attention, you can easily miss it. My sister, my aunt, and myself walked around a couple of times before we figured out that was the place. Maybe it was our lack of direction in that moment...
